title: Baton Rouge forum discusses difficult issues facing community's youth -- and how to help
content: Bullying, violence and drug use were among the topics that nearly 400 educators, social workers, parents and others discussed at a forum Saturday on issues young people in Baton Rouge-area schools grapple with in their daily lives.     Teaching school personnel to recognize warning signs so they can help prevent those kinds of problems was a theme of the fifth annual Prevention Summit, held at the Pennington Biomedical Research Center. The event was hosted by I CARE, a program in the East Baton Rouge Parish Public School System that aims to reduce substance abuse and violence.    It's important to talk with students about how to handle scenarios such as reporting that someone has brought a gun to school, said Susan Thornton, an I CARE specialist. But those who work in the schools should also pay attention to changes in a child's behavior, which can be a clue that they may be dealing with a difficult situation in their life, whether bullying, drug use or another issue.       In the case of kids whose families use drugs, schools can step in to provide mentorship as well as a sense of belonging and involvement. Those are things they may not have at home and that can protect them from becoming drug users themselves, said Jan Laughinghouse, program director for addiction recovery services at Capital Area Human Services.    "It is better to help a child than to fix an adult," she said. "I work with people whose life has broken, and it is incredibly difficult."    Laughinghouse said the number of opioid overdoses has risen in recent years, claiming about 67,000 lives across the nation in 2017. East Baton Rouge Parish has among the highest rates for opioid overdoses in Louisiana, she said, and the state has more opioid prescriptions than it has residents.             East Baton Rouge Parish Coroner Dr. Beau Clark highlighted significant increases to homicide and drug overdose deaths last year, two troubling…        Teachers and other school workers also should be on the lookout for signs of domestic violence — another area of growing concern in the parish — and child abuse.                 Domestic violence cost the lives of 14 people and led to more than 5,000 arrests last year in East Baton Rouge Parish, District Attorney Hilla…        Students may have injuries from abuse, join lots of after-school activities to delay going home or rebel because they're angry about their home situation, among myriad other indicators, said Ellen DeCuir, a counselor at Sherwood Middle Academic Magnet School.    For many of those children, school is "the bright spot in their day," DeCuir said.     She added: "If we can try to help connect them to other things that are available already in schools," like counseling, music programs or sports teams, "that's really going to instill hope and pride in them."
